awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Temblor--an innovative, mobile source of seismic risk understanding and solutions for the public and providers
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to attempt to reduce the largest financial protection gap in the world: the impact of a great earthquake on a major population center. The public is woefully unprepared for such an event, banking on government assistance in lieu of personal resilience. Worldwide, there is $400 billion in uninsured global disaster risk. Even in California, there are 3-4 million uninsured seismically vulnerable homes and a million uninsured vulnerable businesses. People need to understand their vulnerability in terms of dollars and safety, they need to learn how they can protect themselves and their families, and most important, they need to be inspired to take action. This project's free mobile app and blog use public data and models to explain a home's seismic risk, and to show the benefits of buying a seismically safer home, retrofitting an older home, or buying earthquake insurance. Most important, the app and blog do so without scaring, soothing, or snowing the user. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is building a suite of global seismic hazard and risk models that enable the company to forecast the consequences of earthquakes to any building, anywhere on Earth. At every step in the process, the technology rids the models of bias, judgment, or expert opinion, relying instead on algorithmic, reproducible and testable constructs. The company provides insurance agents with sales tools, giving a home or building owner's earthquake score and financial losses in the largest likely earthquake. It provides insurance companies with the means to underwrite (price) insurance, to assess the average annual losses of their portfolios, or to assess portfolio losses at any likelihood of occurrence. For a catastrophe bond whose payment is triggered by a shaking intensity, the company provides the likelihood of attachment over any time period. For a reinsurance company, it provides the ability to compare losses at any or all locations. For a mortgage lender, it provides mortgage portfolio losses, and an estimate of mortgage defaults in the scenario earthquakes to which the lender is most vulnerable. For a multinational company with globally distributed facilities, the technology assesses and ranks their worldwide risk to enhance their resilience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for Temblor, Inc., NSF SBIR Phase II Award 1853246

Summary

Temblor has developed innovative earthquake risk modeling software that helps insurance companies, governments, and financial institutions better understand and manage earthquake risk worldwide. Our NSF SBIR Phase IIB project successfully transformed Temblor from a consulting-based business to a scalable software licensing company, creating products that are now used by major global clients including the World Bank, reinsurance brokers, and insurance companies.

Our technology provides globally consistent earthquake models that overcome limitations of traditional approaches. We've created a 50,000-year simulation of worldwide earthquakes (EventSet), high-resolution site amplification models (SiteAmp), and a comprehensive loss modeling engine (TemblorCAT). These innovations allow clients to better assess earthquake risk, price insurance products appropriately, and develop parametric insurance solutions for vulnerable regions.

A real-world example of our impact occurred in December 2024 when a magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck Vanuatu. Thanks to parametric insurance developed using Temblor's models, the Pacific Catastrophe Risk Insurance Company delivered a payout to Vanuatu just 11 days after the disaster, providing critical funds for recovery efforts. This demonstrates how our technology translates into tangible benefits for communities affected by earthquakes.

Technical Description

The Phase IIB project focused on developing and commercializing three key technological innovations:

1.     EventSet_2025: A 50,000-year stochastic event set for earthquakes magnitude 5.0 and greater worldwide. Unlike other commercial models, EventSet is globally consistent with no national boundary discontinuities. We developed extended source representations for larger earthquakes (M≥6.5) to produce realistic elongated shaking footprints. The model incorporates 70 million simulated earthquakes and has been validated against 117 years of observational data.

2.     SiteAmp: A high-resolution site amplification model that uses digital elevation data to calculate shaking amplification in sedimentary basins. This model provides 50 times higher spatial resolution than the USGS reference model used by other risk modelers, allowing for more accurate risk assessment in urban areas built on sedimentary basins.

3.     TemblorCAT: A comprehensive loss modeling engine that integrates EventSet, SiteAmp, ground motion models, and building fragility data. TemblorCAT enables clients to calculate potential earthquake losses for insurance portfolios. We are implementing this system into the Nasdaq Risk Modelling for Catastrophes platform, making it accessible to a wide range of financial and insurance clients.

Additional technical achievements include developing hazard curves and maps that estimate expected shaking intensity as a function of annual frequency, and creating building fragility models for multiple countries by incorporating 500 building types from HAZUS and the Global Earthquake Model Foundation libraries. Our models have been validated against historical earthquake data and show excellent agreement with observed patterns of seismicity while providing more consistent global coverage than existing commercial models.

Results and Outcomes

The Phase IIB funding enabled Temblor to become a scalable software licensing (SaaS) provider, resulting in growing commercial success:

1.     Product Commercialization: We successfully launched EventSet in March 2023, generating approximately $300,000 in sales. The product has been licensed by QBE, Zurich Insurance, Guy Carpenter, Howden Re, Willis Towers Watson, Fermat Capital Management, and Neuberger Berman.

2.     Client Acquisition: We secured contracts with prestigious clients including the World Bank, Pacific Catastrophe Risk Insurance Company (PCRIC), Gallagher Re, Howden Re, Fermat Capital Management, Neuberger Berman, and QBE. Our work with PCRIC enabled parametric insurance that provided a rapid payout to Vanuatu after a damaging magnitude-7.3 earthquake that also destroyed the U.S. Embassy building in Porto Vila.

3.     Scientific Credibility: We maintained scientific excellence through peer-reviewed publications, presentations at major science and insurance conferences, and university and agency lectures. Our Temblor Earth News site reached about one million readers over our Phase II period, enhancing our visibility and credibility in the field. A recent Temblor-hosted debate on precursory slow slip was watched live by 300 people, and its recording has been viewed by 2,000 scientists worldwide.

4.     Real-World Impact: Our models have been used to develop parametric insurance products for Pacific Island nations, providing critical financial protection against earthquakes and tsunamis.

The NSF SBIR Phase IIB funding was instrumental in helping Temblor reach a strategic inflection point where we can now consider multiple growth paths, including remaining a single-peril modeler, merging to form an all-peril company, or pursuing venture capital funding for further expansion. The project has successfully demonstrated that scientifically rigorous earthquake models can be commercialized and deployed to reduce financial risk and improve disaster resilience worldwide.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/06/2025
Modified by: Ross S Stein

Image
  • EventSet is a globally consistent model of earthquake occurrence, without mosaicking or artificial boundaries. It has been under independent test for a decade, where it has outperformed its competitors.
    Temblor, Inc.
    Copyrighted
    Ross S Stein
    Temblor's earthquake occurrence model, EventSet

Our NSF SBIR Phase IIB project successfully transformed Temblor from a consulting-based business to a scalable software licensing company, creating products that are now used by major global clients including the World Bank, reinsurance brokers, and insurance companies.

These innovations allow clients to better assess earthquake risk, price insurance products appropriately, and develop parametric insurance solutions for vulnerable regions.


A real-world example of our impact occurred in December 2024 when a magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck Vanuatu. Our work with PCRIC enabled parametric insurance that provided a rapid payout to Vanuatu after a damaging magnitude-7.3 earthquake that also destroyed the U.S. Embassy building in Porto Vila.

A recent Temblor-hosted debate on precursory slow slip was watched live by 300 people, and its recording has been viewed by 2,000 scientists worldwide.
